facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2241 of 1970 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 2241 of 1970. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 15, 1969 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 2071 of 1967. C. Setalvad and R. V. Pillai for the appellant.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated April 15, 1969 of Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 2071 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 15, 1969 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 2071 of 1967. C. Setalvad and R. V. Pillai for the appellant. R. L. Iyengar and A. G. Ratnaparkhi, for respondent No. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Mitter, J.

facts.text: Mysore High Court quashed appellant's appointment as University Grants Professor in Sanskrit by Board of Appointments on ground of non-compliance with Rule 5 of Supplementary Rules under Mysore University Act, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal by special leave the appellant challenges the decision of the Mysore High Court quashing his ,appointment as a University Grants Professor in Sanskrit by the Board of Appointments on the sole ground of number-compliance with Rule 5 of the Supplementary Rules promulgated under the Mysore University Act, 1956.

facts.text: Appellant and first respondent have the same academic qualifications.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and the main company- testing respondent have the same academic qualifications.

facts.text: Appellant joined University as lecturer in 1945.

anchor.surface_text: The ,a appellant joined the University as a lecturer in 1945 and he was appointed a temporary Reader in Sanskrit under the University Grants Commission Scheme which was distinct from other University appointments.

facts.text: Appellant appointed temporary Reader in Sanskrit under UGC Scheme.

anchor.surface_text: and he was appointed a temporary Reader in Sanskrit under the University Grants Commission Scheme which was distinct from other University appointments. He was appointed a permanent Reader in the University under the said Scheme in April 1960.

facts.text: Appellant appointed permanent Reader under UGC Scheme in April 1960.

anchor.surface_text: He was appointed a permanent Reader in the University under the said Scheme in April 1960. The first respondent had joined the University as a lecturer in 1938 i.e. seven years before the appellant.

facts.text: First respondent joined University as lecturer in 1938.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent had joined the University as a lecturer in 1938 i.e. seven years before the appellant.- He was appointed a Reader ,under the University Grants Scheme in January 1961 i.e. several months after the appellant.

facts.text: First respondent appointed Reader under UGC Scheme in January 1961.

anchor.surface_text: He was appointed a Reader ,under the University Grants Scheme in January 1961 i.e. several months after the appellant. In December 1965 the appellant was placed as the Head of the Department of Sanskrit.

facts.text: Appellant placed as Head of Department of Sanskrit in December 1965.

anchor.surface_text: In December 1965 the appellant was placed as the Head of the Department of Sanskrit. It appears that in 1967 an appointment had to be made as Professor in the University Grants Scheme, the top position in the department.

facts.text: Appointment to Professor in UGC Scheme considered in 1967 by Board of Appointments for appellant, first respondent, and two others.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in 1967 an appointment had to be made as Professor in the University Grants Scheme, the top position in the department. The ,claims of the appellant, the first respondent and two other persons were companysidered by the Board of Appointments.

facts.text: Candidates interviewed by Board of Appointments; appellant appointed Professor on June 9, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: They were also interviewed by the Board and on June 9,1967 the appellant was given the said appointment. This was later approved of by the ,Chancellor of the University on June 29, 1967.

facts.text: Appointment approved by Chancellor on June 29, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: This was later approved of by the ,Chancellor of the University on June 29, 1967. The first respondent filed a Writ Petition in the High Court challenging the appointment of the appellant under Art. 226 of the Constitution on various grounds

facts.text: First respondent filed Writ Petition No. 2071 of 1967 in Mysore High Court challenging appellant's appointment under Art. 226.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent filed a Writ Petition in the High Court challenging the appointment of the appellant under Art. 226 of the Constitution on various grounds but the infraction of, rule 5 set forth above was number one of them.

facts.text: Single Judge of High Court dismissed writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however on an application made for the purpose allowed the ground to be raised but the learned single Judge dismissed the writ petition.

facts.text: Division Bench of High Court allowed appeal, quashed appointment on April 15, 1969 for non-compliance with Rule 5.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent filed an appeal which was heard by a Division Bench of the High Court. The High Court turned down all but the companytention based on rule 5 above and took the view that the said rule was a mandatory provision ... This judgment was rendered on April 15, 1969.

facts.text: Appellant applied for special leave to Supreme Court on September 9, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants application for a certificate being turned down by the High Court, he filed an application for special leave before this Court on 9th September 1969 along with a petition for stay of the order of the High Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted interim stay on September 22, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: On the application being moved on September 22, 1969 the respondents were directed to show cause why special leave should number be granted but an interim stay was granted to the effect that the matter of a fresh appointment ...

facts.text: Supreme Court order on November 14, 1969 modified stay, appellant to continue as Professor.

anchor.surface_text: On affidavits being filed this Court after hearing the parties passed an order on November 14, 1969 modifying the earlier order of stay to the effect that the order of the High Court was to remain suspended till the disposal of the special leave petition ...

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave on December 11, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: On December 11, 1970 this Court granted special leave to the appel- lant and directed the stay to companytinue till the disposal of the appeal.

facts.text: Mysore University Act, 1956 came into force on October 3, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The position in law appears to be as follows. The Mysore University Act, 1956 came into force on October 3, 1956. S. 13 ,of the Act sets out the authorities of the University which include inter alia the Senate, the Syndicate, the Academic Council and the Board of Appointments.

facts.text: Supplementary Rules approved by Governor on April 8, 1967, published May 25, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Some supplementary Rules of re. cruitment governing the appointment of University teachers were approved by the Governor under S. 26 of the Act on 8th April 1967 and these were published on May 25, 1967.

facts.text: Board of Appointments recommended appointment of appellant (Dr. G. Narulasiddiah) as Professor of Sanskrit on starting salary Rs. 1000 PM.

anchor.surface_text: After interviewing the candidates the Board of Appointments made its written recommendation as follows The Board took into companysideration the academic qualifications, research and teaching experience and the performance during the interview of the four candidates ... unanimously resolved that Dr. G. Narulasiddiah be--appointed Professor of Sanskrit ...

facts.text: Appellant had 22 years teaching experience in 1967; first respondent 29 years.

anchor.surface_text: ... in 1967 when the appointment was made the appellant had to his credit a period of 22 years of teaching experience while the first respondent had 29 years of service to his credit.

facts.text: Appellant preferred over first respondent for temporary Reader in 1958.

anchor.surface_text: It must also be numbered that when there was a question of appointing a temporary Reader under the University Grants Scheme in 1958 it was the appellant who was given preference to the first respondent ...

facts.text: Supreme Court holds appointment valid, sets aside High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we allow the appeal and set aside the order of the High Court holding that the appellant was validly appointed as a Professor under the University Grants Scheme.
he appointment of the appellant under Art. 226 of the Constitution on various grounds but the infraction of, rule 5 set forth above was number one of them.

anchor.surface_text: the sole ground of number-compliance with Rule 5 of the Supplementary Rules promulgated under the Mysore University Act, 1956. That rule provides The Board of Appointments shall give, in writing the reasons for the selection of any candidate and also the basis on which the selection has been made and always give in writing the reasons for overlooking the claims of those who are seniors  i.e. total service as teacher  and or have higher qualifications.

concepts.interpretation: Requires written reasons for selection and for overlooking seniors or higher qualified; interpreted as not making seniority determinative, one factor among many including qualifications, research, interview; substantially complied with if factors considered even without explicit reason statement; irregularity cured by Chancellor approval

anchor.surface_text: Rule 3 of the Supplementary Rules shows that the Board of Appointment was to be provided at the meeting with all relevant information about every candidate regarding his qualification, seniority, teaching experience and research work

under, rule 4 the Dean and the Head of the Department who were to be associated with the Board were to prepare a numbere regarding qualification, work etc. of the candidate who had served in the department under them and give their opinion in writing to the Board of Appointment.

issues.text: Whether the appointment of the appellant as Professor is invalid due to non-compliance with Rule 5 of the Supplementary Rules requiring the Board of Appointments to give written reasons for overlooking seniors

anchor.surface_text: the sole ground of number-compliance with Rule 5 of the Supplementary Rules promulgated under the Mysore University Act, 1956. That rule provides The Board of Appointments shall give, in writing the reasons for the selection of any candidate and also the basis on which the selection has been made and always give in writing the reasons for overlooking the claims of those who are seniors  i.e. total service as teacher  and or have higher qualifications.

issues.text: Whether Rule 5 of the Supplementary Rules is a mandatory provision requiring the Board to state in writing reasons for passing over a senior candidate

anchor.surface_text: the companytention based on rule 5 above and took the view that the said rule was a mandatory provision ... incumbent on the Board of Appointments to state in writing why the first respondent although he had longer teaching experience was passed over

issues.text: Whether there was substantial compliance with Rule 5 by the Board of Appointments despite not expressly stating reasons for overlooking the senior respondent

anchor.surface_text: In our view, rule 5 was substantially companyn-plied with by the Board and the failure to record expressly the reason for disregarding the greater length of service of the first respondent did pot vitiate the appointment per se. At best it was an irregularity which was cured by the approval of the Chancellor.

issues.text: Whether the approval of the Chancellor's under Section 26(4) of the Mysore University Act cures any irregularity in compliance with Rule 5 and renders the appointment final

anchor.surface_text: Under sub-s. (4) The decisions of the Board and in such cases as may be prescribed by the Chancellor, the decision of the Vice-Chancellor shall number have effect unless approved by the Chancellor thereafter, every such decision shall be final and shall number be called in question in any manner.

issues.text: What is the proper construction of Rule 5: whether length of teaching experience is the determinative factor or one among several factors including qualifications, research, and interview performance

anchor.surface_text: In our view the rule was number intended to load the dice in favour of someone merely because of longer experience as a teacher. The Proper companystruction of that rule is to regard the length of teaching experience as one of the important factors to be taken into companysideration by the Board of Appointments.

arguments.claim: Appointment invalid due to non-compliance with Rule 5 requiring written reasons for selection and overlooking seniors

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal by special leave the appellant challenges the decision of the Mysore High Court quashing his ,appointment as a University Grants Professor in Sanskrit by the Board of Appointments on the sole ground of number-compliance with Rule 5 of the Supplementary Rules promulgated under the Mysore University Act, 1956.

arguments.court_reasoning: Rule 5 directory not mandatory; substantial compliance; cured by Chancellor approval

arguments.claim: Rule 5 is a mandatory provision requiring Board to state in writing reasons for overlooking senior candidate with longer teaching experience

anchor.surface_text: The High Court turned down all but the contention based on rule 5 above and took the view that the said rule was a mandatory provision and it was incumbent on the Board of Appointments to state in writing why the first respondent although he had longer teaching experience was passed over

Minister of Housing etc.  1  and Brayhead Ltd. v. Berkshire County Council 2 .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: to bear their own companyts. Before parting with this case we cannot but express our dis- approval

arguments.court_reasoning: Unnecessary to consider in view taken

arguments.claim: Rule 5 not intended to make length of teaching experience determinative factor; one important factor among others like qualifications, research, interview

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves unable to accept the above dictum of the High Court. In our view the rule was number intended to load the dice in favour of someone merely because of longer experience as a teacher. The Proper construction of that rule is to regard the length of teaching experience as one of the important factors to be taken into consideration by the Board of Appointments.

arguments.claim: Rule 5 substantially complied with; Board considered academic qualifications, research, teaching experience, interview performance

anchor.surface_text: In our view, rule 5 was substantially complied with by the Board and the failure to record expressly the reason for disregarding the greater length of service of the first respondent did pot vitiate the appointment per se.

arguments.claim: Failure to expressly record reason for overlooking senior is irregularity cured by Chancellor's approval under s.26(4)

anchor.surface_text: In our view, rule 5 was substantially complied with by the Board and the failure to record expressly the reason for disregarding the greater length of service of the first respondent did pot vitiate the appointment per se. At best it was an irregularity which was cured by the approval of the Chancellor.

arguments.claim: Board's recommendation valid as it considered teaching experience and other factors; appellant had 22 years vs respondent's 29, but prior preferences justify

anchor.surface_text: The recommendation of the Board clearly shows that one of the factors which they had taken into consideration was teaching experience and in 1967 when the appointment was made the appellant had to his credit a period of 22 years of teaching experience while the first respondent had 29 years of service to his credit.

arguments.claim: Giving preference to letter over spirit of rule would invalidate recommendation merely for not stating reason expressly

anchor.surface_text: In our view it would be giving preference to the letter of the rule than to-its spirit if we were to hold that the recommendation of the Board of Appointments was to be treated as invalid merely because they had failed to state, in clear words, that the appellant was preferred to the first respondent although the latter had a longer period of service as a teacher.

arguments.claim: Appointment valid; second Board had no jurisdiction if first valid

anchor.surface_text: Although we have set out what transpired after the presentation of the special leave petition to this Court in September 1969 to give a complete picture of the events concerning the appointment of a Professor under the University Grants Scheme, we do not propose to take any notice of what the Second Board of Appointments did.

holdings.text: The proper construction of Rule 5 is that the length of teaching experience is one of the important factors to be taken into consideration by the Board of Appointments, and it was not intended to make it the determinative factor or load the dice in favour of longer experience.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the rule was number intended to load the dice in favour of someone merely because of longer experience as a teacher. The Proper companystruction of that rule is to regard the length of teaching experience as one of the important factors to be taken into companysideration by the Board of Appointments.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule stresses experience but does not outweigh other considerations like qualifications, research, past experience, interview; purposive interpretation rejects High Court's view that seniority is superior claim requiring stated reasons to supersede.

holdings.text: The recommendation of the Board of Appointments is not invalid merely because it failed to expressly state in clear words the reason for preferring the appellant despite the first respondent's longer service, as this would prefer letter over spirit of the rule.

anchor.surface_text: In our view it would be giving preference to the letter of the rule than to-its spirit if we were to hold that the recommendation of the Board of Appointments was to be treated as invalid merely because they had failed to state, in clear words, that the appellant was preferred to the first respondent although the latter had a longer period of service as a teacher.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Board considered teaching experience (22 vs 29 years) and other factors; past preferences to appellant; giving primacy to express statement ignores substance where factors were weighed.

holdings.text: Rule 5 was substantially complied with by the Board, and the failure to expressly record the reason for disregarding the first respondent's greater service did not vitiate the appointment per se; at best an irregularity cured by the Chancellor's approval.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, rule 5 was substantially companyn-plied with by the Board and the failure to record expressly the reason for disregarding the greater length of service of the first respondent did pot vitiate the appointment per se. At best it was an irregularity which was cured by the approval of the Chancellor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Board took into account academic qualifications, research, teaching experience, interview performance; substantial compliance suffices; s.26(4) provides finality via Chancellor's approval curing irregularity.

holdings.text: The Chancellor's approval under s.26(4) of the Mysore University Act cures any irregularity in the Board's compliance with Rule 5 and renders the decision final, not open to question.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, rule 5 was substantially companyn-plied with by the Board and the failure to record expressly the reason for disregarding the greater length of service of the first respondent did pot vitiate the appointment per se. At best it was an irregularity which was cured by the approval of the Chancellor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory provision in s.26(4) states decisions have effect unless approved by Chancellor, then final; applies to cure non-express recording of reasons.

holdings.text: The appellant's appointment as Professor is valid; the High Court's order quashing it is set aside, and the appeal is allowed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we allow the appeal and set aside the order of the High Court holding that the appellant was validly appointed as a Professor under the University Grants Scheme.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of Rule 5 construction, substantial compliance, curing by approval leads to validity of appointment by Board on 9.6.1967 approved by Chancellor.

holdings.text: If the first Board's action on June 9, 1967 approved by Chancellor was valid, the second Board of Appointments had no jurisdiction to consider the matter again.

anchor.surface_text: Although we have set out what transpired after the presentation of the special leave petition to this Court in September 1969 to give a companyplete picture of the events companycerning the appointment of a Professor under the University Grants Scheme, we do number propose to take any numberice of what the Second Board of Appointments did. In our view, if the action of the Board of Appointments taken on June 9, 1967 and approved of by the Chancellor on June 26, 1967 was valid, the Board would have numberjurisdiction to companysider the matter for a second time.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Validity of original appointment precludes fresh consideration; supports not noticing second board's actions.

holdings.text: Rule 7 of the Seniority Rules (effective 30.3.1969) cannot be taken into account for this decision as it came into force after the appointment.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Setalvad appearing for the appellant drew our attention to Seniority Rules which were framed with the approval of the Chancellor and came into force on 30th March 1969 ... Rule 7 of these rules provides that Teachers appointed to a class of post in the University Grants Commission scale shall be deemed senior to teachers holding the same class of posts in the University scale.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules post-date the relevant events and appointment; not retrospective.
